Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Sanctuary of Apollo (Naukratis) (Attributed by Petrie to the 'second temple of Apollo'.)
Curator's comments: Petrie 1886, 14, notes that the fragment was found in a layer associated with the Second Temple of Apollo containing, among other things, numerous drill cores from calcite alabastra. The engraved decoration on the ostrich egg is not easy to date: a good parallel is the myrtle wreath on the rim of a Caeretan hydria of the final third of the sixth century BC (Boardman 1998: 253, fig. 496); in general wreaths, including myrtle wreaths, are popular from at least the mid-sixth century BC onwards in Greek iconography (Kunze-Götte 2006). Boardman, J. (1998). Early Greek Vase Painting, 11th-6th Centuries BC. A Handbook. London Kunze-Götte, E. (2006). Myrte als Attribut und Ornament auf attischen Vasen. Zurich
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (p. 14, pl. XX, no. 15)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (WA.14)
